In biology, animals with a digestive tract develop along a rostral-caudal axis. Rostral denotes the front of the face, and caudal denotes the end of the tail. (It's easiest to picture in a fish, where development is more linear along this axis.) While the anus (and gluteus maximus in humans) are not always truly at the "bottom", or most caudal, it is developmentally at the caudal bottom of the gastrointestonal tract.

If the term bottom originated in the mid/late 1800s after the discovery of cells & evolution, I wouldn't be surprised at all if "bottom" was used instead of "caudal" or "distal" as a common term.

But... in this video you say something along the lines of,

'Running specialization was naturally selected – actually enjoying all of that running was not naturally selected.'

BUT this is totally untrue. Haven't you ever heard of "runner's high?" The enjoyment of running is an essential part of running specialization. We definitely have different selection pressures now which helps explain why running isn't universally loved. BUT, it absolutely was naturally selected.

It's really quite fascinating research! Science has considered the runner's high to come from endorphin's, essentially opioids produced in the body. BUT it turns out that the endocannabinoid system gets engaged by running as well! Cannabinoids are the active ingredients in marijuana, so running LITERALLY gets you high!

Google "Raichlan et al., 2012 Wired to Run" for a more detailed look :)

A common tactic for a lone wolf hunting is to spook it's prey, and then follow behind it until it's prey is exhausted at which point the wolf lopes up and eats it (the same way that humans hunted back in Kenya a hundred thousand years ago).  I watched this clip of a wolf doing just this on some nature show and it was impressive.  The hunt was filmed from high above in a helocopter and the picture was zoomed in.  A beautiful white wolf bounds out of the bushes and spookes a deer somewhere up in Alaska.  But instead of trying to put on speed, it just loped behind the frightened deer, staying in sight of it as it tried to get away.  Eventually after fifteen miles the deer stumbled and tripped and spilled onto the ground at which point the wolf turned on the speed.  It was over.  And it was bloody well impressive.

In 2007 Florian Holzinger was the second human to win this race. It took him 2:20:30 and was therby 11 minutes earlier at the goal than the fastest rider.
So far no other human managed to win this race, but it will be held again in june this year.

Human approximated world record speed: 45km/h
Horse approximated world record speed: 88km/h

Suppose the world records is the average speeds for the species in a race.

Problem: What is the probability that the human would be able to achieve a speed of 88km/h over the next x unit of time or unit of distance, given that his average speed is 45km/h per x unit of time or unit of distance?

Apply Poisson distribution function:
Probability = P(x<=88) - P(x<=87) = {[(e^-45)(45^0) / 0!] + [(e^-45)(45^1) / 1!] + ... + [(e^-45)(45^87) / 87!] + [(e^-45)(45^88) / 88!]} - {[(e^-45)(45^0) / 0!] + [(e^-45)(45^1) / 1!] + ... + [(e^-45)(45^86) / 86!] + [(e^-45)(45^87) / 87!]} = 0.999999995310287 - 0.999999995310287 = 0

By the axioms of statistical mathematics, the probability is 0, the world record human will never be able to achieve the speed that is achieved by the world record horse.

endurance has very little to do with our butt muscles and more to do with gravity, momentum and inertia. Because of this, it's probably the most efficient way of commute. If you put your leg out to take a step, you change the weight distribution. Extending the other foot upwards, changes the centre of gravity as you push, you change the angle of your body and gravity pulls at a different rate throughout this angle causing forward momentum. As your extended foot hit's the ground, your upper body is still moving, and you just need to let inertia do it's work to "pull" your body. The leg that is now extended, just has to fall and swing forward. This process is repeated, and you find that very little muscle is needed for movement. To make it even more efficient, you can just change your center of gravity by pushing your hips out to the point where it feels like you will fall if you don't extend a leg. Keeping your hips forward from your torso, allows gravity to assist your forward movement. I like to think of it as the body's natural gyroscope. Returning your hips to regular position slows and stops your momentum. I'm confident that utilising forward momentum and gravity in this manner would allow someone to run great distances without loosing their breath because very little work needs to be done by the muscles, therefore heart rate wouldn't rise as much which means less oxygen is needed than someone who runs by pulling themselves with one leg while pushing with the other.

Only problem of humans running large distances is that because we land on our heels instead of our toes (like most animals that run a lot), our knees and ankles are pounded with about three times our body weight each time a foot hits the ground. Runner's knees therefore wear down much more quickly than those of animals. Evolutionarily speaking it's much more likely that humans walked large distances by day in tropical heat (therefore the sweating) and had the capability to sprint a medium distance when necessary.

I disagree that a human can out run an animal for long distance in endurance race. for example the Arabian Horses can run in endurance races for 160 in one day carrying a human at speed 6.6 km/h. A camel can cut 144 km in 10 hours
in speed 14.4  km/h and it  can cut 448 km in three days 6.2 km/h carrying around 250 kg.

I always roll my eyes when people think humans are relatively helpless without technology. Look up pursuit predation. Early humans were basically the Terminator, following our prey until it collapsed. Often, we wouldn't even have to kill it, the animal would already be dead from heat exhaustion. Also, we can survive injuries that would kill most other animals. Even back in the bronze age when medicine was extremely primitive, it was not unheard of to see someone with a lost limb. Fast forward to today: it's pretty damn rare even with modern veterinary medicine to see an animal survive losing a limb.

Dear Michael

There is a clear answer to your main question. 'Fond' (< Lat. fundus, which is cognate to English bottom and German Boden) was used in Middle French to denote the far side of something or a person's body. The original meaning, downside (the ground, soil or floor) was mostly the bottom of barrels whose downside you cannot see if the barrel is filled which yielded into the meaning of far side. 

There are plenty of French phrases loaned into English, thus for instance: from the bottom of my heart < du fond du coeur.

And into German too: The first use of German Hosenboden (seat of trousers) is from 1675 in a grammar of French: le fond des chausses der Hosenboden.

Basically, I'm wondering why, if it's better, we didn't all learn to walk like that or why, if it's not as good as 'regular' walking, it grew to such prominence as an efficient style of movement (for those that needed it anyway) during the Edo period?

I'm sorry Michael, I'm always an advocate of charitable causes but Sport and Comic Relief are not ones that I support. Their practises for raising money involve investing money raised by their events meaning that the money contributed by you won't be used for years to actually help people. Now this wouldn't be an issue but investigations into Sport Relief and Comic Relief have found that the industries that both charities invest most heavily into are in fact the arms trade and the nicotine and tobacco industries, two industries that cause many of the problems that both charities, but particularly Comic Relief, are meant to be solving, because they yield the best and safest return on their investments. Honestly, if you want to help local communities in the way that Sports Relief is meant to, then support local charitable organisations and programmes with your own money directly, and always be sure to investigate how any given charity spends the money that you invest.

Again, I never like downing on people trying to do the right thing, but frankly investing money into arms and tobacco with money meant to help people and children who are starving or have physical or mental disabilities is not how I would want my donations to be used, even if it is for a good aim further down the road.

Pursuit predation. Humans can virtually outlast any viable prey simply by following it at a walking pace. Sure, said prey could be much faster in the short run, but due to humans endurance and ability to retain sufficient amounts of energy without needing to rest as long as said prey, humans can effectively hunt down an animal without having to be faster than said animal.

Humans are scary good at pursuit predation. Imagine being followed by a hungry animal, you can run all you want, but you have to rest eventually. Now as you're resting, you look back and notice the animal - not being as fast as you, but somehow still managing to keep up with you - just simply following you... Waiting for you to just tire out and become an easy meal.

Humans may not be the strongest or fastest of all the animals on earth, but we are the best pursuit predators, which makes us a serious threat compared to the other predominantly predatory animals on earth.

Could humans actually have three butts?

The cut of meat called pork butt is actually from the shoulder of the pig, but is considered inferior to the loins or 'ham' (the actual posterior area of a pig), so it was often packaged rather than sold fresh, and since the barrels were measured in butts as mentioned in this video, these lower quality cuts of pork were called "butts" (the term first used in Boston). Since human beings have a similar fat to muscle content of pigs, and cannibals in Polynesia called consumable humans "long pigs", from a morbid sort of perspective, maybe humans actually have two butts, or three (if you consider each shoulder)?
